importance: This paper is important because it presents a novel **few-shot evolutionary optimization (FSEO) framework** that improves sampling efficiency for expensive multi-objective and constrained optimization problems.  It addresses a significant limitation in existing meta-learning approaches by handling these complex scenarios, providing a **generalized framework applicable to various surrogate-assisted evolutionary algorithms (SAEAs)**.  The empirical results and ablation studies offer valuable guidance for researchers working on similar optimization challenges and opens avenues for future research in **transfer optimization and meta-learning for SAEAs.**
summary: FSEO: A new few-shot learning framework boosts efficiency in expensive multi-objective & constrained optimization by meta-learning surrogates, improving sampling significantly.
takeaways: A novel few-shot evolutionary optimization (FSEO) framework is proposed for expensive multi-objective and constrained optimization problems.
The FSEO framework utilizes a meta-learning approach called Meta Deep Kernel Learning (MDKL) to leverage experience from related tasks and improve surrogate model accuracy.
Empirical studies demonstrate that FSEO enhances sampling efficiency compared to existing methods, particularly in scenarios with limited evaluation budgets.
tldr:
Many real-world problems involve finding the best solution under limited resources and complex constraints, a challenge tackled by expensive optimization. Existing methods often struggle with multi-objective scenarios (multiple conflicting goals) or constrained ones (restrictions on possible solutions).  These methods usually train models from scratch, limiting efficiency.
This paper introduces FSEO, a new framework using a technique called meta-learning to train surrogate models.  Instead of training from scratch for every problem, FSEO learns from related, smaller problems, transferring this experience to improve the performance on the main task.  Experiments show that this approach is highly effective at improving sampling efficiency for both multi-objective and constrained optimization problems, especially when evaluations are costly.
